item.title: Baldur’s Gate 3 Dev’s Previous Massive RPG Is Now Officially Out For Modern Consoles
item.content:encoded:
At the top of the attention-seeking tree at this year’s Game Awards was Larian—the massive independent studio behind 2023’s most fantastic game, Baldur’s Gate 3—with their silly statue in the desert and then the most astonishingly unpleasant trailer for their next RPG project, Divinity. I couldn’t be more thrilled about the prospect of returning to Rivellon, but given there will be years left to wait for that, I’m instead delighted to notice that the previous game in that series, Divinity: Original Sin II, is now officially updated for Switch 2.

2017’s release of DOS2 was the moment Larian really established itself as one of the all-time leading RPG developers. The Divinity series began with the decent enough action-RPG Divine Divinity in 2002, followed by the decidedly mediocre Beyond Divinity in 2004, which was slammed for its crappy story and lack of originality. Things didn’t improve enormously in 2009 when Divinity II came out riddled with bugs, dragged down further by a poor Xbox 360 version, but they started to look up a year later when an improved and much-fixed re-release appeared and won people over. Things went quiet for a fair while, with the peculiar but successful decision to release a real-time strategy game set in the same universe in 2013, but it was in 2014 that Divinity: Original Sin appeared and blew everyone’s socks off.

The plot thinnens.

With a 93 Metacritic score, the award-winning Divinity: Original Sin 2 is now yours to play on Nintendo Switch 2, Xbox Series X|S, and PlayStation 5!

Upgrade for free or begin your adventure today and prepare for what lies ahead.

youtu.be/_K_vKMo7DEI?…

— Larian Studios (@larianstudios.com) 2025-12-15T15:46:30.537Z

Suddenly this studio known for somewhat generic action-RPGs appeared with an epic, old-school, party-based RPG that was delighting crowds. Its story was still its weaker area, but this was like a butterfly compared to Larian’s previous caterpillars. However, it would be three years later than every single element would come together into one glorious whole with the release of Divinity: Original Sin II, one of the all-time best RPGs ever released.

Funded by Kickstarter and released into Early Access in September 2016, a year’s development followed in communication with its community, and this seemed to be the magic ingredient Larian needed. That, and releasing a beefed-up, improved and lengthened Definitive Edition a year later.

The game was so good that it allowed hundreds of thousands of people to feel extremely smug when Baldur’s Gate 3 broke through to the wider mainstream in 2023 (following its own Early Access), knowing they were there before it was cool. But now, with the announcement of Larian’s next project Divinity, an awful lot of people are going to want to go back and fill in the gaps.

If you’re one of those people, you really don’t need to worry about anything before DOS. You can pick that up on PC, Xbox and PlayStation. But honestly, if I were you, I’d just dive straight into the sequel. It’s a standalone story, and it’s a superior game. It’s one of the superior games! And now it’s been given a sprucing up to shine on modern consoles, including the Switch 2.

I’m absolutely psyched for an excuse to play it all over again. I’m going to pick this up for Switch 2, and I’m going to remember to get the trait for speaking to animals from the very start. (Seriously, if you don’t, you’ll miss out on so much.)

item.title: TP-Link Wi-Fi 7 Adapter Drops to an All-Time Low, Making the Upgrade From Wi-Fi 6 Cheaper Than Ever
item.content:encoded:
If your current laptop or PC lacks built-in wireless capabilities or only supports outdated Wi-Fi standards, adding a dedicated adapter to the setup can get you the speeds you’re looking for. TP-Link makes some of our favorite wireless connectivity solutions out there, and right now, you can grab a solid adapter by the brand without paying the full price.

The TP-Link BE6200 Tri-Band Wi-Fi 7 wireless USB 3.0 adapter archer is currently available for $80 at Amazon, after a nice 38% or $50 discount. This is the lowest it’s dropped to in the last 90 days, which means it’s one of those leftover Black Friday deals that survived the chaotic event. Such deals, however, tend to wrap up fast, so it’s best to grab yourself a solid adapter while the discount is still live. Getting your orders in today should help them arrive before Christmas, which is great if you’re planning to stream or game with friends during the holidays and don’t want slow internet speeds ruining the experience.

See at Amazon

Reliable Signals

This USB 3.0 adapter comes with two bifurcated high-gain antennas and a detachable cradle with a 1.2-meter cable. The beamforming technology helps direct the Wi-Fi signal towards your router for incredible reception and more reliable signals, even from farther away. When it’s paired with a Wi-Fi 7 router, you can enjoy the 6 GHz band that further improves wireless performance with 160MHz, Multi-RUs, and 4K-QAM. The 6 GHz band offers speeds of up to 2,882 Mbps, while you’ll get 2,594 Mbps on the 5 GHz band, and 688 Mbps on the 2.4 GHz band. These translate into ultra-fast downloads, smooth gaming, and better 4K/8K streaming.

The powerful combination of OFDMA and MU-MIMO technology lets you connect a bunch of devices to your router at the same time, without compromising on the speeds on any of those. Setting everything up couldn’t be any simpler. You can plug the adapter directly into the USB port of your device, or place it nearby using the cradle. The Archer TBE401UH is compatible with Windows 11/10, plus it comes with a preloaded driver, meaning you won’t have to worry about following any complicated installation processes to get started.

Those who take cybersecurity seriously (as everyone should) will appreciate how TP-Link is a signatory of the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency’s (CISA) Secure-by-Design pledge. The adapter is built and maintained with advanced security. On top of that, the latest WiFi security protocol improves encryption to protect your Wi-Fi passwords and defend against online attacks.

This tiny but mighty device is now down to $80, and is sure to solve all your PC-related internet issues for good. We’d recommend grabbing it at its retail price, too, but the current deal makes it a no-brainer. Be sure to grab it before the retailer decides to push the price back up for good.

item.title: The 10 Worst Games Of 2025 According To Metacritic
item.content:encoded:
We got a lot of great games in 2025. Some big, some small. But not every game released over the last 12 months was good. Some were meh. And others, well, others were downright terrible.

As we’ve said before, the best games are only great if we can compare them to mediocre or awful games. And 2025 had plenty of these to choose from. So let’s take a look at some of the worst-reviewed games of 2025.

But before we do that, it’s worth repeating once again that liking a “bad” game isn’t a bad thing. Numbered scores come with all sorts of caveats, which is part of the reason we don’t use them at Kotaku. And Metacritic’s aggregate isn’t perfect by any stretch. If you see a game on this list that you happen to love, don’t get mad, just smugly nod to yourself and remind yourself that the critics got it wrong.

Now, as we’ve done in previous years, here are the 10 worst-rated games on Metacritic (they had to receive at least four reviews to qualify).

10: Fast & Furious: Arcade Edition | 45 Metascore

Even priced at $30, this budget racer port of a so-so arcade game isn’t worth it. You are better off dropping a few quarters into the original arcade version and playing for a few minutes of nonsense before realizing it has little to offer and moving on.

9: Glover |  44 Metascore

Glover is back. I’m so sorry. This port of the OG N64 platformer that someone liked, surely, isn’t much of an upgrade, and even if it was, this is still Glover we are talking about, folks. It’s lucky to make any list.

8: Scar-Lead Salvation | 44 Metascore

Wait a minute, this game has the same metascore as Glover, and yet it is worse? Yeah, I’m ranking it below Glover as it has more reviews, so more people didn’t like this pricey and basic anime spin on a Returnal-esque roguelike shooter.

7: Ambulance Life: A Paramedic Simulator | 44 Metascore

Oh, and look at that, one more game that landed at a 44 Metascore. Ambulance Life slides just below whatever the last game was because even more people played, reviewed it, and didn’t like its AI-generated dialogue, clunky gameplay, and ugly visuals.

6: Tamagotchi Plaza – Nintendo Switch 2 Edition | 43 Metascore

This sequel to Tamagotchi Connection: Corner Shop falls flat on its face because it plays like a bad mobile game and has some truly repetitive minigames.

5: Gore Doctor | 40 Metascore

Gore Doctor is the first game on the list that I had never heard of before, and now that I do know about it, I’m happy to have avoided this horror game that is apparently a technical mess with terrible controls.

4: Spy Drops | 39 Metascore

Someone wanted to make a stealth-action game like the OG Metal Gear Solid. Sadly, this game is bogged down by a lot of problems, including a bad camera, bugs, and brain-dead enemy AI.

3: Blood of Mehran | 38 Metascore

Critics really disliked this Prince of Persia-like action game, with nearly every review calling it some form of terrible. Avoid at all costs.

2: Fire Emblem Shadows | 37 Metascore

What if Among Us, but Fire Emblem? That was seemingly the pitch for this mobile-only Nintendo-published dud. Even the few good ideas are overshadowed by free-to-play garbage and a lack of content. I’d probably just play Among Us instead.

1: MindsEye | 28 Metascore

lol, yeah that seems right.

Smarter Tools Designed to Boost Productivity

One of the most helpful additions to Windows 11 Pro is Universal Search, conveniently placed right on the taskbar. This feature acts as a centralized search engine for your entire device and beyond. Doesn’t matter if you’re hunting for a PowerPoint file, trying to pull up a recipe you saved months ago, or quickly checking a location on a map, Universal Search streamlines the process. Instead of digging through folders or juggling browser tabs, you now have a one stop shop for anything you’d ever need to find in a single search bar.

The operating system also shines with its improved Virtual Desktops feature. By enabling Task View, you can build multiple customized desktops tailored to different aspects of your life. You can have one desktop dedicated to work, another for entertainment and browsing, a third for launching all your games, and perhaps a separate one devoted to creative projects. Each virtual desktop can sport its own layout, wallpaper, and shortcuts, helping you maintain organized spaces that you can switch between them effortlessly.

Don’t forget about some of the several lesser-known keyboard shortcuts that can noticeably speed up your day-to-day tasks. A great example is the Win + V command, which opens your clipboard history. Unlike the standard Ctrl + V function, which pastes only your most recent copied item, Win + V lets you select from multiple previously copied clips. item.title: Star Wars: Fate Of The Old Republic‘s Director Promises It Will Arrive Before 2030
item.content:encoded:
Good morning, and welcome to your previously scheduled Monday. Don’t watch the clock, and this terrible day will end soon. Until then, enjoy this installment of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‘s daily round-up of video game news and other stuff you might care about. This time around, we get an update on Fate of the Old Republic, check in on Fallout Shelter, and perhaps sing that famous Grinch Christmas song.

Casey Hudson denies claims that FOTOR is five years away

During last week’s Game Awards, Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic was revealed, and people got excited. A spiritual successor to Knights of the Old Republic led by that game’s director, Casey Hudson, who also helped create Mass Effect? Heck yeah. But, as pointed out by a few different reporters, this new Star Wars game is being developed by a studio that’s just a few months old and so, folks speculated, the game was likely a long way off, possibly not launching until 2030.  This speculation quickly snowballed into full-on “rumors” and spread like wildfire, without proper context online, eventually leading to Hudson publicly denying the 2030 date on social media.

“Don’t worry about the ‘not till 2030’ rumors,” posted Hudson on December 12. “Game will be out before then. I’m not getting any younger!”

And while I’d love to be playing FOTOR sooner rather than later, I am curious as to why Hudson is so confident that something as large as a new KOTOR-like Star Wars RPG can be developed in under five years by a team that was just formed a few months ago. Maybe they have a super solid, streamlined plan with lots of support and resources to spare? Or maybe Hudson found a genie lamp? Regardless, according to Hudson, FOTOR will be out sometime before 2030. Place your bets now.

10 years later, and Fallout Shelter just got its biggest update ever

Mobile bunker-builder Fallout Shelter has been around since June 2015. And despite its age, Shelter is still extremely popular, receiving ports to console and PC and numerous updates. Its most recent one, out now, is its biggest yet, adding seasons, new characters, quests, and more connections to Amazon’s live-action Fallout show.

“Rejoice, Overseers – Fallout Shelter’s biggest update yet is here,” explained Bethesda on the game’s Steam page. “Years of content previously only available on mobile is now available on Steam, including new questlines, characters, weapons, themes, and more.” It ain’t Fallout 5, but at least it’s something.

Arcade1Up might have shut down over the weekend

Over the weekend, as reported by Time Extension, an email was shared online that seemed to indicate that Arcade1Up, a company that specializes in creating modern arcade cabinets, was shutting down. The reported internal email, which was sent on December 10, claims that Arcade1Up shut down on December 12 and that the future of the brand is unknown. At least one dev studio that had worked with the arcade makers has already indicated that its classic ports will still support online play via a backdoor that players will be able to turn on in the future if the shutdown affects online servers. So far, Arcade1Up has yet to confirm or deny the reports of its demise.

Katamari Damacy’s creator might be done making games after To a T sold poorly

Keita Takahashi, the creator of Katamari Damacy, released a new and odd-looking game this year, To a T, and if that’s the first you’re hearing about it, well, you aren’t alone. Apparently, the famed creator says the game didn’t sell well, and it has potentially forced him out of the game industry.

“I recently returned to Japan, and one of the reasons I had to do so was because To a T didn’t sell well,” Takahashi recently told GamesRadar. “My next goal is to support my children and find them a school in Japan. Then, if I feel that I don’t belong in the games industry, I’ll have to look elsewhere.”

It’s a real shame that an offbeat game like To a T, struggled to find an audience in 2025, and when the developer was asked if there was still room for weird, experimental games in the industry, Takahashi said “I’m not sure” and admitted that it’s “definitely” become harder for him to make these kinds of games anymore.

item.title: Lenovo Idea Tab Becomes the Cheapest Android Tablet With a Holiday Discount, Lowest Price of the Year
item.content:encoded:
Tablets make it incredibly easy to stay both productive and entertained on the go. These are also great for students who don’t want to carry a huge laptop to college and are looking to take notes or work on assignments digitally. The Lenovo Idea Tab does an excellent job at that, and Amazon is letting you pick one up without spending a ton.

It typically goes for around $240, but thanks to a nice 25% discount, you can grab yourself one for just $180. The tablet comes with a pen for easy navigation, plus a folio case, which makes it safe to carry around. The deal is open to all shoppers, but it’s likely to ship after Christmas. If that’s not an issue, we suggest jumping on the discount as soon as you can!

See at Amazon

Packs a Punch

The tablet flaunts an 11-inch 2.5K IPS touchscreen display. It delivers sharp visuals while actively reducing blue light emission to keep the screen comfortable on the eyes; great for exam season, where you might need to pull all-nighters with it. The display is nicely paired with immersive sound, thanks to quad Dolby Atmos-tuned speakers. You will be able to take online lectures comfortably, while still enjoying your study breaks by squeezing in an episode of Stranger Things to take your mind off complicated maths problems.

Four learning apps – including Lenovo AI Note, Squid, Nebo, and MyScript Calculator – come built in. These let you write down important points during the lecture, organize tasks, sketch some diagrams, and perform basic mathematical calculations without needing to install another program. Performing quick Google searches has never been easier, either. A quick circle around items or text pulls up the answers you’re looking for, and it even translates content into your preferred language without switching to another app. The included Lenovo Tab Pen takes the experience even further. It makes it quite convenient to scroll, swipe, draw, and jot thoughts down.

Behind the scenes is a powerful MediaTek Dimensity 6300 processor working tirelessly to keep everything running smoothly. The 8GB memory lets you do a bunch (using multiple applications, switching tabs) without experiencing noticeable slowdowns, while the 256 GB built-in storage offers plenty of space to store all your important files and programs. You will be able to keep all your essential programs, group presentations, final year projects, and more in a single place without feeling limited.

As for the battery, you can expect around 12 hours of continuous use on a single charge. That’s enough to go at least two days without worrying about plugging it in. And finally, the included case lets you prop the thing up anywhere you want, with stability. You can use it in the classroom, cafeteria, on your way back home, and even on the couch easily.

All of these features come together to make the Lenovo Idea Tab one of the best tablets for students and work professionals on the market. It’s made to handle work and play efficiently, and the long battery life makes it quite easy to carry with you when you’re out and about. Be sure to grab it before the deal expires if you want to avoid paying the full $240 for it. Once the discount is gone, we don’t expect it to be back before New Year’s.

item.title: 2025’s Break-Out Roguelite Megabonk Gets, Er, Spooky For The Holidays
item.content:encoded:
Megabonk, a 3D reimagining of Vampire Survivors that became one of 2025’s surprise hits, has somewhat belatedly released its Halloween update just in time for the winter holidays. But hey, Christmas has always been spook-adjacent, right? There’s A Christmas Carol, Krampus, A Charlie Brown Christmas…

“yoo I’ve finally finished the update I was working on,” said solo developer Vedinad in a post on Steam. “Was originally going to be a small halloween update, but I wanted to make it a bit bigger so it turned into a bit more work than I initially planned.” He goes on to list the new content added in the Spooky Update:

  • New Map
  • New Character
  • New Weapon
  • New Items
  • New Enemies and Bosses
  • New Achievements and challenges

Megabonk is an unabashed reinterpretation of Poncle’s Vampire Survivors, albeit with a few original twists of its own, not least that it’s now a 3D, third-person action game. It came out in September this year and absolutely exploded in popularity almost right away. And deservedly so! It’s a great game, even if most of its ideas aren’t entirely original. It also came out a couple of months ahead of Poncle announcing its own reinterpretation of Vampire Survivors as a 3D version of itself, although in that case it’s also being combined with a deckbuilding roguelite.

Alongside the new elements listed above, the Spooky Update also comes with a bunch of bug fixes, some new “advanced” settings for very niche tweaks, and a host of balancing changes. There’s also access to the game’s console, with the intention of making the game more open to speedrunning. And even this update has since received an update, fixing a few issues the spookiness introduced.

The game’s well worth checking out. A lot of people already have, to the degree that it was nominated in this year’s Best Debut Indie Game category at the Game Awards, before the pseudonymous developer withdraw it from consideration on the basis that it’s not really his first game. (Something the category’s eventual winners did not choose to do.)

item.title: Logitech G Driving Force Shifter Drops to Its Lowest Price Ever, Compatible With Racing Wheels and Pedals for Xbox, PS5, and PC
item.content:encoded:
With Forza Horizon 5 making its way to the PS5 earlier this year, now’s the perfect time to jump in and enjoy one of the standout racing games of this generation. To elevate the experience even further, you’ll want the right gear—something that makes it feel like you’re in the driver’s seat. The Logitech G Driving Force Shifter for PlayStation, Xbox, and PC is currently seeing a major price drop. Normally $60 on Amazon, it’s now discounted by 17%, bringing the cost down to just $50 for a limited time.

As funny as it would be to use the Logitech G Driving Force Shifter alongside a standard controller, I’m afraid that’s not possible. This product is part of a larger kit. Logitech’s G Series racing setup is crafted for maximum realism with a driving wheel, pedals, and this optional shifter. Real race cars are manual, not automatic. So if you want to complete your driving simulation setup, you’ll need this last piece of the puzzle.

See at Amazon

The Logitech G Driving Force Shifter is compatible with Logitech G29 and G290 Driving Force Racing Wheels in order to enhance your experience behind the wheel. The shifter plugs in via cable to the rear side of your Logitech driving wheel.

You get real, quality construction that has the weight and feel of an actually shifter you might find in your own vehicle. It’s made with a solid steel gear shaft. The knob and boot are covered in a high-quality hand-stitched leather, which makes it look and feel like the real deal. It’s also durable and can put off wear and tear for a long time.

The shifter can be securely mounted to your driving rig. The lever is designed to be grabbed and pulled around, so the whole unit needs to be able to hold it’s ground while you race. That’s why it has built-in clamps and bolt points. The clamps just twist on either side to screw into a secure fit, then you push down the knobs to lock it into place. Easy peasy.

Ultimate Precision

Using the six-speed shifter is fluid. You’re met with a satisfying, tactile click as you shift between each gear. You’ll be able to execute smooth, accurate gear transitions whether you’re speeding up down a straight away or coming out of a turn. Pull down to put your rig in reverse.

Aside from just enhancing your experience playing a racing game, a driving sim like this makes for a not so bad method of learning to be behind the wheel. Particularly if you’ve only ever driven automatic, this can provide a safe way to learn how to drive stick. If you travel a lot, especially in Europe, you’ll find that renting an automatic is far more expensive than renting manual. Plus, you’ll have a lot more options of vehicle choice with manual. It’s a good skill set to have.
